sub_topic: Find the curvature and torsion of a space curve.
message_1:
A particle moves along a space curve given by the parametric equations:

x(t) = 2cos(t)
y(t) = 2sin(t)
z(t) = 3t

Find the curvature and torsion of the curve at t = π/4.
message_2:
To find the curvature and torsion of the curve, we first need to find the first and second derivatives of the parametric equations with respect to t.

First derivatives:
x'(t) = -2sin(t)
y'(t) = 2cos(t)
z'(t) = 3

Second derivatives:
x''(t) = -2cos(t)
y''(t) = -2sin(t)
z''(t) = 0

Now, we need to find the tangent vector T(t), the normal vector N(t), and the binormal vector B(t).

Tangent vector T(t) is the first derivative of the position vector r(t) = <x(t), y(t), z(t)>:
T(t) = <x'(t), y'(t), z'(t)> = <-2sin(t), 2cos(t), 3>

Normal vector N(t) is the unit vector of the derivative of the tangent vector T'(t):
T'(t) = <x''(t), y''(t), z''(t)> = <-2cos(t), -2sin(t), 0>
To find the unit vector, we need to find the magnitude of T'(t):
||T'(t)|| = sqrt((-2cos(t))^2 + (-2sin(t))^2) = sqrt(4cos^2(t) + 4sin^2(t)) = 2
So, N(t) = T'(t)/||T'(t)|| = <-cos(t), -sin(t), 0>

Now, we can find the curvature k(t) using the formula:
k(t) = ||T'(t)|| / ||r'(t)||^3

First, we need to find ||r'(t)||:
||r'(t)|| = sqrt((-2sin(t))^2 + (2cos(t))^2 + 3^2) = sqrt(4sin^2(t) + 4cos^2(t) + 9)

Now, we can find the curvature k(t) at t = π/4:
k(π/4) = ||T'(π/4)|| / ||r'(π/4)||^3
k(π/4) = 2 / (sqrt(4sin^2(π/4) + 4cos^2(π/4) + 9))^3
k(π/4) = 2 / (sqrt(4(1/2)^2 + 4(1/2)^2 + 9))^3
k(π/4) = 2 / (sqrt(4 + 9))^3
k(π/4) = 2 / (sqrt(13))^3
k(π/4) = 2 / 13^(3/2)

Next, we need to find the binormal vector B(t) using the cross product of T(t) and N(t):
B(t) = T(t) x N(t) = <-2sin(t), 2cos(t), 3> x <-cos(t), -sin(t), 0>
B(t) = <3sin(t), 3cos(t), 2cos^2(t) + 2sin^2(t)>
B(t) = <3sin(t), 3cos(t), 2>

Now, we can find the torsion τ(t) using the formula:
τ(t) = (B(t) • N'(t)) / ||T'(t)||

First, we need to find the derivative of the normal vector N'(t):
N'(t) = <-sin(t), -cos(t), 0>

Now, we can find the torsion τ(t) at t = π/4:
τ(π/4) = (<3sin(π/4), 3cos(π/4), 2> • <-sin(π/4), -cos(π/4), 0>) / ||T'(π/4)||
τ(π/4) = (3sin(π/4)(-sin(π/4)) + 3cos(π/4)(-cos(π/4))) / 2
τ(π/4) = (-3/2) / 2
τ(π/4) = -3/4

So, the curvature k(t) at t = π/4 is 2 / 13^(3/2) and the torsion τ(t) at t = π/4 is -3/4.
